Aquarium of the Bay.name: Aquarium of the Bay
reviews: modestly Interesting exhibits but WAY over priced

$26.30 per person and you will see everything in less than an hour if you really milk it. The river otters playing are the best part. The glass tunnel through the fish tank though the curved plexiglass distorts depth perception and size. Lots of local fish including large sturgeon and a variety of bay sharks. Some of the exhibits missed the mark. I didn't visit to see South American tortoises or pet-store chinchillas or an interactive dinosaur animation. I was looking for all local aquatic and riparian critters. The ray petting pools and tide pool mock-up are cool. On the down-side, the exhibit plaques are written to uphold Eco-extremism ideals, painting fishermen as villains. So when you finish the exhibit, go to any local diner & have a big fish dinner, without which Fisherman's Wharf would not exist.
Show less
If I had a do-over, I would have skipped this aquarium. It is relatively small and pretty dated in my opinion. I'm not sure we spent more than a half hour here (and I'm generally a fan of aquariums).
We used our GoCard for our admission. This isn't the largest aquarium, but it has fascinating sea life to see. Children would live it.

This is a cute little aquarium that has a fun staff and a good location. The juvenile otter was the best. My Son took off his hat and waved it my the water tank and the otter followed the hats movement.

We got into this place free,due to our bus hop on hop off ticket,BONUS It was lovely,we got to gently feel a sting ray.We saw beautiful,playfull otters,they were just gorgeous.Loads of fish as well,and sharks and rays.Very interesting and staff very friendly and welcoming

Very inexpensive and simply amazing. Great staff, knowledgeable and friendly. The aquarium will amaze you with each step.

Do the behind the scenes tour

Great variety of Bay creatures. We were the only people on the behind the scenes tour ($17 each). It was interesting to see how the Aquarium works. You get a view above the tanks looking down (the fish are larger then they look in the tunnel). Afterwards we went into the exhibits and were impressed. The otters are very cute and watching the feeding was entertaining. We love the augmented reality feature and they email photos to you (free ). Gift shop had reasonable prices and variety.
Show less
Quite small, but interesting and for a cause

Compared with other aquariums, the Aquarium of the Bay in Pier 39 of San Francisco is quite small and has a limited collection of sea animals on display. This may result a bit disappointing when admission ticket costs $27. Console yourself knowing that every time you visit this aquarium, you donate a small amount for the conservation and protection of the San Francisco Bay and of the animals that thrive in it. In fact, 88 cents of every $1 you pay go to such a program.

The area is divided into two levels ... the Entrance Level (where you'll meet Tahoe, an otter; have a chance to touch some sea animals, like star fish, small rays and sharks; etc.) and the Bottom Floor (with tunnels and glass containers for jelly fish, octopuses, and so forth).

Perhaps the interesting part of the visit to this aquarium is the feeding time of the animals. Be sure to check the schedule as you enter the place. On your way out of the museum, on the same Entrance Level, you'll find a gift shop. Now be sure to keep you ticket, because it also entitles you to visit the EcoCenter at Heron's Head Park and the Bay Model Alliance in Sausalito. Also visit the Sea Lion Center at K dock for free to observe the sea lions of the Bay.
Show less

If you want to be amazed and frightened at the same time. Go to the Aquarium of the Bay. So many beautiful ocean species to ponder over. There are also many otherworldly and strange creatures to run away from. Fun for the family for the whole day. It never felt overcrowded and very easy to navigate. Enjoy your trip to another world.

This would be a cute thing to do if it was half the price. And on top of it, they actually have the nerve to change the ticket prices whenever they want for no reason. I had gone on the website to look at tickets on a Monday or Tuesday. The family pass was $70 (for 4 people). When I went back on the website 2 days later, I thought I was going crazy or something...it was $80. The only reason I went is because I promised my daughter many times. From what I hear, there are much better aquariums.

This wonderful aquarium, located in Embarcadero and Beach Street, is a lively place and ideal to bring young kids. Should visit while in San Francisco. Beauty of this place is they display local aquatic animals which tourists won't find back in their countries.
They have different pricing packages depending on your age & group sizes.

The Aquarium of the Bay is not huge, but there are a few interesting exhibits. I loved the colorful fishes and the touch pool with the baby bat rays. It is really special to touch the soft skin of them. The tunnel tank with the sharks and fishes is cool. The various types of Jellyfishes are beautiful and don’t miss the little Pacific Tree Frogs. My highlight was the gorgeous otters. They were in a playing mood and I could watch them a long time. I enjoyed the visit and spent almost two hours there.

A good place especially for families with young children, as there is a lot to see and gives a fascinating overview over wildlife native to the area and also more exotic species.

Took two year old grandson to tour this aquarium. The two level site was staffed with friendly staff. You can avoid the nearby ticket booths and go direct to the ticket booth at the aquarium.

My family visited the Aquarium of the Bay, while we were on Fisherman's Wharf. It was one of the attractions included in the City Pass. It is a small aquarium with 3 floors accessed by elevator. Small aquarium, but still fun to visit; especially enjoyable for youths

The Aquarium of the Bay on San Francisco's Pier 39 is focused on marine life in the bay and neighboring waters. This aquarium comprises two levels; visitor start their tour in the "Discover the Bay" exhibit on level 3, then take an elevator down to the "Under the Bay" exhibit on level 1, where they walk through two underwater glass tunnels. Finally, via the elevator, they return to level 3, where there are few more exhibits such as "Touch the Bay" and the river otters.
There is no "main hall" to this aquarium, just three passageways separated by the elevator. The walkthrough of the entire aquarium ends as quickly as it has begun so enjoy while it lasts! Plus, young children will especially enjoy the "Touch the Bay" exhibit as they get to lay their hands on the living creatures.
The main highlight of my visit was walking through the tunnels, as various sea creatures of swam along and above me as I walked past. I also thought the river otters were quite adorable. Sadly, my tour through the aquarium ended in less than half an hour. Prior to the tunnels, I got a cameraman to snap photos of myself to highlight my visit; however, when I reached the gift shop to purchase the photos, the clerk told me that I can only obtain hard copies, not digital copies.
For a better aquarium in San Francisco, I would suggest the one in California Academy of Sciences in Golden Gate Park.
Show less
Nice and fun for kids. 100% non for profit and most of their collection goes directly to conservation work.

We were visiting in California for a family reunion, and had our 12 year old granddaughter with us who had never been to San Francisco. We only had one day to visit SF and were debating where to go.

We settled on the Pier 39 area/Fisherman's Warf area, a cable car ride and China Town. Although the traffic was challenging, we were able to drive to the Pier 39 parking garage with relatively little trouble and walked across the street to Pier 39.

My granddaughter wanted to go in every shop, be we herded her over to the aquarium, paid the admission and began the tour. The first exhibits were very nicely done with a wide variety of sea life, and very helpful staff who would answer your questions.

The next exhibit was down an elevator where we entered the aquarium section which included an very neat exhibit of jellie fish, an underwater walk through tunnel of shallow water animals such as rock fish, then an exhibit of abalone and octopi, finally the deep water creatures of the bay, including a number of sharks.

We entered the elevator again to go up to the second floor where they museum had exhibits where you could touch sea creatures (under supervision) including a shark, rays, turtles, tide pool animals and others. These animals had all been rescued and would be dead if they were not her. The staff helped people and answered questions about the animals

The final display were a pair of twin river otters that had been rescued, which appeared to appreciate the audience by performing constantly when people came to watch, and reclined when there was not audience!!!

There was, of course, a gift shop...and the really neat thing was that over 80% of the revenue from the gift shop and admissions went back into conservation work!

We spent about 1.5 hours in the aquarium, and could have come back an watched some more (the give you a stamp on your arm for admission for the day) if we didn't have some other things to see and do. My granddaughter loved it, especially the exhibit where one could touch the animals. She particularly liked the rays which would come by and raise a "wing" for you to touch....

The Academy of Sciences also has a large aquarium and planetarium, as well as other very interesting exhibits, but would have consumed the entire day, and has an understandably higher admission fee


has an interest in animals and debated wher

You walk through aquarium tunnels with marine life around you including small sharks, see smaller tanks with different animals and a few land creatures as well. This was one option with our city pass. I wish we would've used it on the DeYoung museum instead. It's not bad, just very underwhelming. The otters were cute and the walk through tunnel was cool but that's about it. The California Academy of Science had more sea life than the aquarium.

Great for the kids, very interactive and interesting Went on a Sunday evening, lots of people but not too crowded. Tunnels were amazing!! 🐟🐟🐟

San Francisco's Bay Aquarium
This aquarium is in the small side, BUT it contained SEVERAL WORTHWHILE EXHIBITS!

There are four main components of the aquarium: discover the bay, under the bay, touch the bay, and highlighting animals.

For us the clear tunnels where you can view see marine animals such as fish, shark, starfish, etc was a highlight for us. I suggested if you want to feel like you have the aquarium to yourself, go very early, when it first opens. We were able to see much of the aquarium without crowds. The tunnels were just phenomenal!

There were two sets of tunnels. One displayed the marine life that would be seen in the Bay Area at 20 feet below the surface of the water. The next tunnel shows the animals that would be living at 90 ft below the surface of the water in the Bay.

The Touch the Bay Area was also very good. You could touch a stingray, sea anenome, sea stars and anything else there. The staff were great help.

Another Bay Area was the river otters exhibit. They were so much fun to watch. Very lively creatures.

I felt felt the prices were very reasonable. For adults it was $24.99 per ticket. As I said before, if you go early you'll get a better feel and be able to take your time and really enjoy it.
Show less

My granddaughter loves aquariums, so we check this one out. The only exhibits worth seeing are the underwater tubes.and the otters. If you have smaller kids and young teens they will love the touch and feel section. Touching a stingray is so exciting for them, and the stingrays love to be petted. Again, as an adult, I been to much better, but for kids it is fun and something special for them when many things seem boring for them. We spent a lot of time trying to get good photos for my granddaughter in the tubes.

We realize the Aquarium is a non-profit, but it is badly in need for updating and improvements. We had a City Pass, but if we had paid the admission, we would have been very disappointed. Spend over 30 dollars per person to see like 10 tanks? It is the tiniest aquarium I have ever been to. The only reason to go is if you want to pet a stingray (bat ray), or starfish and sea cucumbers. No large sharks or anything, just the small fish you would find off the coast of San Francisco.

From looking at the other reviews, it seems the two biggest complaints are that it costs too much and it’s not that big. From a cost standpoint, it is $25 for adults and $15 for children. While I would say it may be slightly overpriced, but then again it would be much faster to list places in that area that are NOT overpriced so it didn’t bother me.

As for the size, I can understand where they are coming from as it’s definitely not a big as other aquarium’s like The Shedd Aquarium in Chicago. I think we pretty much saw everything in 90+ minutes. However, that was fine with me because there are so many entertainment options in the area, I don’t think we would have stopped by if it would have taken all afternoon to hit all of the exhibits since our time in the area was limited.

The highlights from our daughter was going through the two tunnels with a fish tank on both sides and overhead, being able to touch the stingrays, and seeing the baby otter and shark. The bottom line is we had a good time and glad we came.

Very nice aquarium, but also a small aquarium. From the outside you really shouldn't be that surprised though. Not a large selection to see, the tunnels are average for the size. Very nice staff and clean. Gift shop there. Great for small children.

While the glass tunnels here are decent, this aquarium has less sharks and rays than other, more moderately priced aquariums we have visited. The staff is very friendly, but this should not cost around $100 for a family of four. It's worth around half that. It's actually a tiny aquarium. The petting section is teeny, with very few creatures you can touch. Most of the animals in this part of the attraction are not in touching station. There are two random chinchillas. On the second floor, there are two otters. I've been to several otter exhibits with many more animals.
Show less

The aquarium is really small, the lookout below is cool but for the price it was a really quick activity.
Show less

My husband and I went with our daughter, son in law and grandchildren and enjoyed the visit. The aquarium is nicely laid out for a quick visit. We particularly enjoyed the touch pools and underwater tunnels. It's a good place for younger kids but I don't think I would recommend it highly for teens or just adults.
Show less

I went with my family when they were visiting me in SF. I live in San Francisco but had never been there . The aquarium was very small and the amount of different species were very limited . I personally think $22.95 for a ticket is too highly for this very small aquarium. It should be more like $12.00. I would recommend you skip this attraction and spend your money on something more worthwhile .
Show less
Well done Interactive, nice lay out

If you do a lot of aquariums then you will like this one. It is quick and easy, well laid out. The Otter exhibit is active, they have touch pools, and a very large underground tunnel water exhibit. 95% of the fish and sea life are local.

Note: best time to go is between 6 and 8pm, not crowded, and you can spend your time looking at the exhibits
Note: get a city pass, then you do not feel like you are paying an arm and leg for various small exhibits that the kids want to go to
Note: when you are done, go see the seals at the end of Pier 39
Show less
While a bit pricey, and it is small I enjoyed the short little adventure through the aquarium. Interesting displays and touch pools. Great place for younger kids.
Had a good time- interesting to see. But I've been to much nicer aquariums. Give yourself about 45 minutes to get through. You're able to go back and forth to the aquarium until it closes.

Worst aquarium ever! Overpriced! Save your money! Dingey! Small and disappointing. More life a death trap the way they move you thru elevators! No real sharks, dirty water, nothing to see. Go to Baltimore and see a real aquarium!! Trust me- don't go!!!!!
Show less

I was so disappointed in this attraction. We were in and out in 25 minutes. Had we purchased the City Pass I wouldn't have been disappointed so much, but to think that I paid out $65 for a family.

Then there was the $35 for the obligatory entry photos - though I had the good sense not to ruin these with my presence and just shoved the kids in - which turned out well and I was happy enough paying out for the two large prints and the two small framed prints.
Show less

Yes it was interesting. Like looking into a giant underground aquarium. A bit like the one in Jaws. Fascinating to see the sharks and jellyfish close up. And s whole variety of other fish. Family enjoyed the visit. We found our Alcatraz visit more exciting.

Took our 3 year old grandson and his parents here. This is a great little aquarium with very interesting and interactive exhibits. It is nothing like the Steinhart Aquarium which is very large and very comprehensive. But for families, especially with children this one is better suited. Also great if visiting Pier 39 and have an extra hour or two.
BTW
Locals, which included us from the East Bay, get a significant discount. It is relatively expensive so the discount is great.
Show less

As aquariums go it was ok, it was however very small, it look less than an hour to go round the whole place and stop to take several pictures .... and no octopus even though it had been advertised and there were lots of plastics models of one
Show less

It was OK, I don't begrudge paying towards conservation (by purchasing entry) but it was pretty average. Having seen Aquariums around the world (Cape Town, Dubai, throughout Europe and Asia) it let me down in the small size, limited diversity and layout. Undoubtedly doing a great job in the local area but the exhibits were disjointed.
Show less
one of the weaker aquariums i've been to

I've been to Monterey Bay, Aquarium of the Pacific, and Georgia aquarium and I really enjoyed those but this one, even though my hopes were not high was just not very good. Pricy for what you get and not very much to see, your better off going to the Academy of the sciences which is really neat. On the positive side the Shark tunnel is very nice, the touch tank is actually pretty good, and the staff are nice and have good information so the aquarium isn't completely awful but very lackluster.
Show less

We spur of the moment decided to go to the Aquarium. The walk through tunnel is amazing! It was not over crowed or crazy busy. Gabriella was absolutely wonderful!! We asked her loads of questions and she answered them all and then some. She gave us facts on the sharks and other various fish. We looked forward to seeing her come by us so we could ask her more questions. We also saw her up by the touch pool. She was fantastic with children and adults. She was patient and approachable! Gabriella is a definite asset to your staff!!!! She made our experience above and beyond wonderful!
Show less

Brought my 3 year old granddaughter here and she loved it. I found it to be very clean, the employees are very knowledgeable and friendly. You literally walk through the tunnels of fish, they are swimming above you and around you. They have a hands on tide pool that was little kid perfect.I love that everything you see is what is found right here in our bay. The tickets good all day long with in and out privileges. The only con, I found it very pricey for what they offer you see everything in 30 minutes or less depending if you linger or not. they offer a family special of $70. 2 adults 2 kids. The offer a military discount and a discount if you live in the surrounding counties. If you park in the Pier 39 parking don't forget to validate your ticket at a sit down restaurant, that runs you $9.00 an hour weekdays, 10 weekend, unless you find street parking good luck with that. I gave it 3 stars because of the price.
Show less
Really nice aquarium. Seeing the large grouper, jellyfish and sharks was really special. Walking through the tubes was great as the fish and sharks swam all around you.
Something to do to past the time
Me and Becky went there yesterday and it was pleasant. You saw lots of varieties of creatures that live in the water. My highlight was touching some creatures especially the rays
Aquarium is worth a visit, especially if the weather is bad. You can easily spend a 2 - 3 hours there if you like watching the feeding and 'touch' areas.

A god aquarium with the ultimate walk through underwater walkway. Guides on site to fill the kids full of knowledge and fun. The interactive section is particularly good for the children. You can re-enter at your leisure so get a stamp.
Cute place and a nice visit

The aquarium is small, but it does have some great things to see. The jellyfish and the underground aquarium are great. Come during feeding time! I'm glad we came but don't expect to spend much time here

Nice aquarium, not best one in world but has lots of interesting local marine life and good explanations of how life cycles work and threats to it. Staff is friendly & helpful. Several cool jellyfish displays. Allow an hour, tops, here unless you have someone who's really into this. We enjoyed the aquarium at CA Academy of Sciences just as much.
Show less
Small but good for a couple of hours.

We got tickets as part of a 3 day pass. My 19 month old son loves fish. The upstairs is a small, typical aquarium. The downstairs has a nice jellyfish display and 2 large walk through tunnels, that are really the highlight. We went through the tunnels twice because my son loved them so much. At the end is a rive4 otter exhibit, but they were sleeping while we were there. Good way to pass an hour ir so, but you won't be there much longer than that.
Show less
What's there is nice. But there's not much there.

This is the smallest and least interesting aquarium I've been to, and it wasn't that cheap. There is an initial room with some local fishes that looks like 1/10th of the similar exhibit at Monterey Bay. Then there is a room with a few jelly fish. Then a tunnel through the big tank where they have sharks (Leopard and maybe a sand or two). Then there is a touch-tide-pool (ONE FINGER ONLY) and then some cute river otters, which was the highlight. All told, five rooms and it costs $25 for adults give or take. I would take and give my money to another attraction.
Show less

My grown son wanted to visit the Aquarium. You enter and see some of it then take an elevator down and then an elevator up. It was fun to walk under the overhead aquarium. There was a touch and feel area. This is one of the many Aquarium's I have been to. I think I heard them say it was non-profit... but not sure. Otherwise comparing others this one was a little disappointing. But they did make good use of their space and maybe because of the crowd of people couldn't get to some of the things they offer. If you have never been to an Aquarium of this sort ..... THEN IT IS A MUST !!
Show less

I’ve been to several different aquariums. This ranks as kind of average. It’s got some cool stuff. I love the ocean and its creatures so I’m always intrigued. However, it’s not a place I would spend several hours. You can basically see it in an hour. It’s worth a stop but it’s certainly not a destination and wouldn’t be something you would write home about.
Show less
Just not worth the money or effort.

We literally saw this in 30 mins. Was so disappointed. Very little to see and with it being so expensive I would say definitely NOT worth going!
Show less
Good Aquarium , Great place for families to go.

Aquarium has a good diverse group of sea creatures. Kids are especially focused on the exhibits. Therefore this aquarium is a place for families. They have a long tunnel under the water that is a very nice attraction. Reserve at least an hour.

We spent a few days in San Fransisco while journeying through California. Our boys wanted to see the Aquarium while we were at Pier 39. It was almost $100 for four of us and it was literally the worst Aquarium that we have ever been to. Price is definitely not worth the limited amount of experience. Save your money and enjoy the seals at the end of the Pier!
Show less

We spent a couple of hours visiting the Bay Aquarium and it was a pleasant visit however there isn't much wow factor to it. I think the most interesting parts were having the ability to touch some rays and starfish and watching the otter training. I've been to several aquariums and this is not one of the best.
Show less

This aquarium is not in the same league as Atlanta or Baltimore so don't expect too much. It is however a wonderful experience that teaches you about the local ecosystem in a very hands on way. I'm always happy to contribute to local causes that will teach our children the importance of the the environment. If you have 1-2 hours to kill or just want to get out of the cold this is a perfect spot. We could have spent another hour watching the otters play. Remember, every dollar you spend goes toward keeping this place running so make sure you visit the souvenir shop afterwards.
Show less

We had high hopes for this place, given that it represents the bay's rich marine life, but it was surprisingly small and underwhelming. The large tank you can walk through was fairly good, featuring seven gill sharks, sturgeon, and rays. But we've seen better and larger tanks in Toronto and Chicago. The interactive tank for the rays was also quite small. We did enjoy the otters, as we happened to be there in time to see the training and feeding time, which was great. I'd skip this and just go to the California Academy of Science. Their aquarium doesn't have sharks, but it's bigger and much better.
Show less

Worst aquarium I have ever been to and I went to one in Thailand that cost me 50cents to get into so that's saying something. Very disappointed especially with the cost of entry.
Show less
It was okay, but nothing special

As far as aquariums go, this one was pretty mediocre, which is unfortunate because it's right on Pier39. It was cool that your paid admission is good for 24 hours, but there's not that much stuff to see, so it's not really an effective perk. If you've been to ANY aquarium, anywhere else, then there's no reason to visit this one.
Show less

The aquarium is very nice with lots of attractions. The varieties of species of water animals is a pleasent to see. The aquarium is situated on the banks of ocean which makes us feel happy to spend an hour or two. It's not a big one but kids truly enjoy. But the entry fee is more which is a minus point. Many in the Bay Area are unaware of this aquarium as I feel. The management has to reduce the entry fee to make middle class people to afford the fee. Nice one and a weekend jaunt to enjoy the place.
Show less

We thought we could kill some time in the afternoon before dinner and check out the aquarium. In and out in less then an hour wish there were more things to see and do there. I realize that it's non profit but I did feel it was a little pricey for what you get. Loved that we could touch the stingrays, shark, and star fish. The kids really enjoyed that part.
Show less

Title says it all really. It is not big (which baffles me, with it being in the US), but there are some tanks with lovely creatures, like lit up jelly fish. There is also a touch-pond or whatever you call it. The enclosure for the otters seemed a touch on the small side, so that would be my only complaint.
Show less
Great small aquarium in the heart of the Wharf!

When you come to Fisherman's Wharf, you're probably not thinking that there's an aquarium here for you to visit. For you aquarium connoisseurs, you're missing out if you don't stop by this place. I think I came here for the first time after I left the bay area which is a pity because this is probably my second favorite aquarium here in California. Yes it is located on the pier and you think from all their advertisements that it's just a tourist trap but it's a good one!

If you parked at the Pier 39 garage you get $2 off a general adult ticket so be sure to use it. You take an escalator upstairs and prepare for a several level experience of all the bay's sea creatures. You start off with some of the more tropical fish that you don't get too much here in California but as you go deeper and deeper you'll see displays of jellyfish, kelp forest fish and many others. Take a trip downstairs and your adventure continues with more local fish and then the shark tunnel.

Even the shark tunnel features fish from the local area including the 7 gill shark which is the largest shark that is endemic to the area. Yes, there are great whites too in SF bay but not all that common. They had large sturgeons, rays and guitarfish which are always fun to see. Your trip ends with a lot of reptile and amphibian displays followed by 3 playful male otters that are a hoot.

Park at Pier 39 for all your Fisherman's Wharf shenanigans. While the price is initially startling, your discounts make up for it and also the headache of trying to find somewhere cheaper to park would offset it as well.
Show less
O.K., but nothing special compared to other aquariums

For the entrance fee, I expected a lot more. It was the usual assortment of smaller tanks with a variety of tropic fish, a few local small mammals and reptiles, and of course, the walk through tanks with rays and sharks as well a a number of other fairly large fish. At the end, there is a tank with otters, which they staff was feeding when we were there. I wasn't happy that they made the otters do tricks for food!
Show less
The staff was very friendly, but It was a tiny aquarium. It's a convenient location if you're already on the piers.

Nice little venue. We went as a family of four and experienced the walk through tunnel and got to touch a snake, starfish and sea anemones. Friendly staff and easily accessible. We purchased our tickets in advance through Groupon (much cheaper deal).

This trip was so amazing how everything is set up to view. Being able to touch curtains sea animals was amazing and the jellyfish and shark tanks were so awesome with them swimming over you. They had huge fish to exhibit and they had the tiniest fish. Great place to experience and to take the family we will be going back very soon with our children. Great learning experience.
Show less
Great Place to Get Out of the Rain

We were planning on spending a touristy day at Pier 39, but it started to downpour. So instead, we walked over to the aquarium of the bay and spent a very enjoyable few hours exploring. The best part of the aquarium are the 2 glass tunnels. We must've spent at least an hour walking through the tunnels and observing the fish, the rays and the sharks. I felt like a young kid on a school field trip. As an aside, I was a little disappointed about two things. First, despite advertising all over town with pictures of an octopus, there was no octopus at the aquarium. Apparently, the last one was there four or five months earlier. And secondly, near the end, there is a large sea otter display, but not much to see. In fact, we could only see one, way in the distance and only its head popping out of a rock. But otherwise, it was a very fun activity.
Show less

Tiny little aquarium. Most exhibits were commonly found in other aquariums. Kids would find it fun as they could gently touch the sting rays. Did not take much time to go through. Barely spent a couple of hours there. Good that it was part of the San Fran city pass.
Show less

I rated this as average - average for an attraction. It's interesting with what it has. However, as an aquarium, I would have to rate it below all the aquariums I've been to (including the one in Albuquerque). This wouldn't be as bad if not for the price; $25 a person is a lot for something that will only take about an hour to go through, even if you go slowly. (The Albuquerque aquarium costs half that.) And you're forced to go in a certain order and really can't go back. Save your money and see the sea lions in the wild for free.
Show less

We bought the SF city Pass and it included entry to this. I would choose to go to the aquarium portion of the CA academy of science or the Monterrey Bay Aquarium. It was worth visiting as part of a package though. The location is very convenient on Pier 39 since we were right there. It was extremely crowded when we went over Christmas break. My husband liked the table were they dissected a squid. My daughter liked the touching table where you could hold and feel some creatures. They have a stingray exhibit where you can reach in and feel them. It is deeper than it appears and I saw many kids get their sleeves and even coats very wet. Also a fun exhibit was the otters. They have a glass wall so you can see them swim under the water and come up on top and see them too. I think I would have been more impressed if I had gone here BEFORE going to the CA academy of science museum. It was fun enough though if you can't get to another aquarium.
Show less
This is Not your Monterrey Bay Aquarium

We spent a little while visiting the Aquarium by the Bay. It is definitely NOT your Monterrey Bay Aquarium. But if you have little children they might enjoy the visit. And we supported the Bay conservation, I guess, by our visit.
I loved it! sharks tank and sea otters are so cute! You can touch mantas and starfish and shark`s tank is amazing!
Great aquarium , good way to spend a couple hours with the kids

This small aquarium really packs a punch in a small place , we had a wonderful time and we walked through the tunnels twice because the kids enjoyed it so much , if you are a member of a reciprocal zoo you can get in for half price , check your zoo to see who they are members with , most are
Show less
Great little aquarium on the pier
What a nice little aquarium right on the pier. Very cool seven gill sharks and rays. Staff is very knowledgeable and helpful. Otters were cute.

Cute, small aquarium. It took us just over two hours to walk through and we were going pretty slowly. The highlight is the tunnel, we happened along while divers were feeding rays and anemones. Something to do for a bit if the cost isn't an issue.
Show less

This is a must see aquarium. There is an aquarium tunnel that you walk through, a see lion observatory, and a 'petting station' for many kinds of sea life. We were able to touch sea cucumbers, star fish, a small shark, and some sting rays, among other things. So cool!!
Show less
Otter feeding time was the highlight

We bought City Passes which included the aquarium. It would have been expensive for the short time you would stay there. There are jellies, a touch pool, a walk through glass tunnel that was a bit murky and other interesting animals. Our highlight was seeing the otters being fed. They could do more tricks than our dog! Every staff member was very friendly and knowledgeable. We stayed about 1 1/2 hours
Show less
Not enough sea-life variety for us

We come from Vancouver, BC, and there we have an aquarium with endless sea life - including whales, dolphin shows, 4-D shows, endless fish of all sizes, etc. Here in San Fran, the only neat things we saw were the large shark tube tank (where it feels like you're walking under water watching all the sharks swim by & over top of you), and the few otters we saw playing in the snow. Other than that, the variety of sea life was quite lacking at this aquarium. For the expensive price we paid, we weren't too impressed.
Show less

The aquarium is a small privately funded aquarium with rather limited exhibits. We visited the aquarium as it was included in the CityPass package which we had purchased. There are 2 floors of exhibit and we went through them in about 20 minutes. I would suggest to give it a miss especially if you are buying tickets separately.
Show less

So not as instructional as other aquariums I've been too. But given the touristy location still a learning experience. Definitely has a cool factor that i did not expect. The guides/workers were super nice & friendly. My family loved the jellies & sharks. I had a City Go SF Pass so waa happy with being covered attraction in the pass.
Show less
If you're in San Francisco add this to your list of things to do.

I really enjoyed my trip to the aquarium. Friendly staff, some great exhibits and I love love love the otters!nteresting reading the information that is up. There is an exhibit where you can touch things in the tank too.
On Pier 39 so can be incorporated into a day trip with other things. If I'd had more free time I would have booked the backstage tour.
Show less

So glad we made this a stop! Not a very large aquarium, but very nicely done with a lot of great information. Located at Pier 39 (also part of the Citygo pass) it was easy to get to and we learned a lot. Especially about the sea lions that hang out at the pier 39 harbor! There is also another portion separate from the aquarium at the top end of the pier with more info which we would never have known about. Very worthwhile and great walk under the sea to see the sharks
Show less

We just didn't feel like this had enough bag for the buck. Apparently there is an octopus exhibit, but that was all down while we were there. We did enjoy the otters at the end, but otherwise this was kind of ho hum. We had been at another aquarium in Crescent City that had much better exhibits and was much cheaper. Spend your money on something else, like the Exploratorium!

A decent attractions but not as good as other aquariums

It was a decent attraction.I've been to other aquariums before and this one was ok.It has touchtanks and a tunnel into a aquarium where sharks and other fish would swim above you and around you..They had other cool exhibts.Its just a decent aquarium because its not as good as other aquarium I've been to.I liked this aquarium but it wasnt worth the price to get into the aquarium..It was just decent..If this was my first time goting to an aquarium If probably rate it better.I was expecting something better or just as good as other aquarium I've been to into the past.The Omaha,Nebraska Zoo has an Aquarium bigger than this one.Shedd Aquarium in Chicago,il is huge.Even the aquarium here my hometown of Kansas City..has a better aquarium in the Crown Center area in Kansas City.I still liked this aquarium its just that it wasnt as big as the other aquariums and all that interesting as the others I've been to.

The price would have you believe that the aquarium would offer a few hours of viewing pleasure; however it's so small you can be done in 30 minutes even if you wonder slowly.

We have been to many aquariums around the US,this was one of the lower on the Totem poles. If was just Bay fish, nothing exciting at all. For 25 bucks a person, stay home. Cool jelly fish .. but that's about all. A bummer

There are some great views to be had from the upper levels of the aquarium- both of the city and the bay. The aquarium hosted a "Fish Eye View" of Bay Area waters, including how the ocean dwellers have adapted to the litter left behind by those of us on land. The exhibits were well done and most were hands on interactive a for kids. More than a few tourists let their kids run wild, but it actually made it kind of fun- they were really excited to see sharks and an octopus and the jellies. If you're at the pier it's a great place to spend a little time and learn something besides shopping for knickknacks on the boardwalk!
Show less

I enjoyed the layout of the different levels to view. I especially enjoyed the touching room, I was able to touch and feed the stingrays and baby sharks as well as the starfish. The tunnel of marine life was also breathtaking also.
Good place for the entire family! I especially loved seeing the otters! There's a nice gift shop located inside the aquarium. I found a lot of reasonable priced souvenirs!

My wife and I visited the Aquarium of the Bay in SF while on vacation. My wife is an aquarium fanatic so we have visited many across the country. I have to say that this one was one of the biggest disappointments of our trip. Our City Pass ticket booklet offered a visit to either this aquarium or the Monterey Bay Aquarium. We opted for the Aquarium of the Bay due to convenience of it being located in SF so we wouldn't have to rent a car to get to Monterey, bad choice. The aquarium is small, difficult to access, dark, dirty and has very limited options. To me it seemed like a little more than a glorified pet store. The highlights of the visit was the walkway through the main tanks (the moving walkway was broken) and the sea otters which my wife loved. The otters were very active and playful which was the only saving grace from a 1 star review here. Children may enjoy this aquarium but they may also be disappointed due to the lack of exhibits. I would save your money or rent a car and visit the Monterey Bay Aquarium.
Show less

Great place for all ages! I loved looking at all of the jellyfish! An impressive underground tank has all of the local sea life (sting rays & leopard sharks were my favorites) that you are completely surrounded by. You also get to touch baby sting rays & starfish. My kids loved it!
Show less
I have to say, I was disappointed. This aquarium is more like a house with a few bath tubs. There is not much to see here.

Got a voucher for the Aquarium with my City Pass and I'm glad I paid a visit. All the sea life is local to the Bay so it's interesting to see what's under the sea you're looking over. There was a huge sea bass that was being fed by divers, not the sort of thing you normally get to see. The psychedelic jellies were great and there was some otters too. Definitely worth a visit, you only need a couple of hours in there so can combine it with plenty of other things to make a full day.
Show less

The aquarium is worth a visit to once again walk through a glass tunnel and see sharks, sturgeon, rock fish etc. swimming around. The touch pool is interesting to let you feel the surface of the marine animals (sea cucumbers were the strangest). The attendant on duty made quite sure that touching was with one finger only - and was policing that. It was also nice to see a couple of otters swimming furiously around.
Show less

I took the ferry from Tiberon (highly recommended, but that is another review) across the bay with my 8 year old granddaughter. We were walking around when she saw the aquarium sign at Pier 39 and begged me to take her. What could a grandmother do? We went in, of course! This is a non-profit organization that highlights the wildlife living in the San Francisco Bay, for the most part. That is why it isn't as large as other aquariums, but it is still interesting and educational. We watched the seven-gill sharks being fed and learned facts about them from the guide. My granddaughter got to look a moray eel in the eye by way of a plexiglass bubble in the eel's exhibit. We touched bat rays and other creatures in the touch tanks (and yes, there are staff members watching). I am all about learning experiences with my children and grandchildren, and this fit the bill for an afternoon.
Show less
They put animals lives in danger!

EXTREMELY DISAPPOINTED AND ANGRY!!! I am a 16 year old girl who went to this aquarium expecting it to be really fun. Despite it being incredibly dull, the staff were not doing their jobs! When my mother and I were viewing the touch tank, 4 girls (around my age) were picking up and relocating starfish, sea cucumbers, and various other creatures. Not only were they moving them (and breaking the two-finger touch rule!) they were picking them up out of the water and kissing them and taking several pictures with them. You might be asking yourselves, why didn't the staff put them in their place? Oh well it's because they staff weren't there. There was no one watching the touch tank where LIVING ANIMALS could have been stolen, hurt, and even KILLED! My mom and I brought this to the attention of one worker, but all she did was call for some one to come to that post. When someone finally arrived, the girls had left. When we were ending out trip, we stopped in the gift shop and while I was filling out their surveys, my stepdad overheard a worker telling someone the price of the pictures you can buy. We had gone earlier and they had told us it was $5 more expensive than what they had been selling it as now. Sounds like some stupid teens trying to make some extra cash if you ask me. After we returned to out hotel I called the aquarium ready to tell them about all of the things that they had done wrong. No one answered. I left a voicemail and it has several months later. No one ever called me back. This trip made me extremely angry and I can promise you that I am never going back to this aquarium again.
Show less
A fun time on the Pier

We were visiting Pier 39 and noticed the Aquarium. Everyone wanted to go inside. This a a not for profit that benefits the local sea life conservation. It is small but there are a lot of fun exhibits. You start in the area seeing sea life in tanks and the walk thru area where the fish are swimming all around you is great and fun. Then you get to the area you can touch the sea life. There are Sting Rays, star fish, Sea Anemones and more. After this you get into an area with otters playing and they are fun to watch. The kids really enjoy this. This if fun for an hour or 2. Especially with young kids.
Show less
I took my 2yo here & she loved it. Cool little exhibits as we walked in including Nemo & Dory then downstairs to underwater tunnels to see big fish & sharks. Nice finish with some reptiles & otters.
Small aquarium, ideal when pressed for time. Interesting jellyfish and otters exhibitions. Fun for all age groups.

Purchased the San Fran Go Card, I highly recommend that. This was one of the attractions included. We spent may be 1.5 hours there while we took advantage of the other sites on Pier 39. Great for children and adults as well.

Visited the Aquarium of the Bay for an afternoon spent at Pier 39. Found the aquarium a enjoyable experience. Love the underwater tunnel and it was really nice to have staff members close by to answer any questions. They were very knowledgable and friendly. Also loved the river otters, fell in love with their cute faces. We even saw "Dory" from Finding Nemo which was a nice treat. I really enjoyed the jellyfish also. Everything was layed out nicely and the time to get through it at a managed pace took about 2 hours which was just perfect. Two minor recommendations: 1. There should be more benches inside the aquarium for those with disabilities to sit down. We found that to be a little lacking and 2. Please reduce the prices of the picture that they take of you and then offer to purchase. I did buy the picture (although not the complete package) and for 1 4X7 picture was $26.00 which I felt was sort of a bit of a rip off. If the prices were lowered slightly, you would probably have more people that would purchase them. I would visit here again and would recommend anyone visiting to check it out as its well worth it. Also, the ticket prices are very reasonable.
Show less

My husband and I had a few hours to kill on our last day and decided to visit here. Tickets are $25 ... a lot in my opinion for what you actually see inside. We were done in about 45 minutes and probably would have been through sooner except we had to dodge a lot of kids and babies in strollers. The shark tunnel is good and they do have several small tanks of exotic fish. The poor sea otters looked so stressed out. One had OCD swimming back and forth in a small space and another was gnawing on some bark and spitting it out.
Show less
Nice way to spend an hour

I visited the San Fransisco bay aquarium with my partner. We were just walking passed and decided to stop by the ticket booth on the footpath. They lady in the booth was friendly and welcoming. It was not to expensive but also not cheap. It was not the biggest aquarium I have ever been too but it was a nice way to spent a hour walking in the under water tunnels looking at all the Sharks and Rays swimming around.
Show less
Got discount coupon online when I googled the aquarium. Small but excellent aquarium. Loved the jellyfish on display. Staff were very knowledgeable and helpful. Glad we visited.

We didn't visit the Monterey aquarium as it was $50 a person, so this one seemed a bargain at $25 each! But of course, it is much smaller and with less exhibits.
The emphasis is on conservation, and education as to what can be found in local waters (with a tank of exotics thrown in for good measure)
The tank of anchovies is a lovely sight, but really, is that a big enough tank for so many??
We liked the tunnels and spent a long time waling back and forth identifying the fish, The giant Sea Bass is a bit of a scene stealer. Until you get to the shark tunnel, where sharks and rays float alongside or above you.
The jelly fish displays are visually stunning and the video of the octopus unscrewing the lid of a jar to get his lunch is strangely hypnotic.
Its worth mentioning that you will NOT see sea otters here. They hey have 3 river otters as the last exhibit. We noticed repetitive swimming action here, a bit like when a tiger treads the same route over and over and over again in his zoo enclosure.The staff did mention how they try to keep the otters mentally stimulated, but I can't help wondering if its really necessary to keep any of these creatures in captivity for our amusement? We went to learn about the fish but the otter exhibit left us feeling a bit uneasy.
The touch pools are a big draw for the children.
Show less

staff was awesome, there is a shark section, otter section and more. I got to touch baby stingrays and baby sharks.

This is right on the pier 39 area. They took a pic of us which was cool you had the option to buy at the end of your time there

I took a ton of pics
Show less

I agree with others: the place is so small (basically two -very cool- tunnels and a few exhibits and sea otters) and not cheap. Kids will probably like the pools where you can touch different fish and the staff were very friendly and told little stories. However, I wouldn't go again (and could have lived without going at all :/ )
Show less

If you have been to aquariums before this one has to rate as one of the most boring and lacking in substance. It's quite small and does not have a very big variety of sea life. The underwater tank you walk through is very limited in the volume of sea life and its dark and dim. I guess it won't surprise that the fish and sea life from San Francisco Bay are lacking in colour so its not a very exciting viewing experience. The jellyfish exhibit is good but there's not a lot of information available to read on them and the touch pools are small and not exciting. It's not a cheap place to visit and overall I recommend giving it a miss, I want that 45mins I lost back......
Show less

This is better for kids than adults - although a bit pricey at $25 for adults. It's a small aquarium with a limited number of exhibits. Need to take an elevator to get to different floors.
Although staff tried hard, the shark feeding was poorly done. People were bailing on that after a few minutes.
Big focus on protecting environment and marine life. If that offends you, don't go.
Show less
Stop The Complaining, Does Take Time See

Wow wow wow! So many complaints, many people saying so expensive, takes under hour to see! Hint or advice, if you have a Zoo Membership to your home town, your home state, it is reciprocal! For Los Angeles Zoo Members think is half price, for us in Oakland and San Francisco, is free! The last few times me or I been here, takes good three so hours! Maybe people/guests are not listening to the docent talks, maybe they not staying for the feeding of the different animals!

One docent, I was reading how in October 2011, Governor Jerry Brown, (YES OUR FORMER MAYOR IN OAKLAND) signed into act a bill banning the cutting of fins on the sharks! I also learned there really a species of shark call SOUP FIN SHARK! Okay, so the docent say yes the bill was signed, as of January 2013 the restaurants and the stores can or could only sell remainder! Once all that sold, no more of the divers going into oceans, cutting the fins, throwing back the sharks! They will die, just think, if someone cut off your hand, your arm, threw you back into wherever, eventually you also die! Glad he signed this! Yes shark fin soup popular at sixtieth birthday parties and at weddings, I just glad he signed this! There were also musk rats, otters, sea stars! I even saw froggies (ribbit ribbit)!

This a great place! Not sure the entire admission fee, as say, Oakland Zoo members are reciprocal! Have not yet purchased post cards, maybe one day! The aquarium is smart, to get to necessary rooms, have go through gift shop, as say so far have not yet, but may one day purchase post cards!
Show less

As it comes with City Pass; I went. You might not feel that it is of good value if you are not bringing children and the place is small. Smaller than the aquarium at Seattle. I spent 40 minutes in it. Come early!

Coming from Omaha, with a beautiful Aquarium included in the admission price at the Henry Doorly Zoo, the Aquarium of the Bay is an over-priced, under-sized tourist trap. While there are some nice features overall, it's just not worth the price of admission for this one small place. Several of the attractions were unstaffed (touch tanks), so nothing to see there! It was nice, but disappointing. My opinion is that it was added just to put something else on Pier 39 to suck in your bucks! We got sucked in -
Show less

We were walking along the pier, and decided to see the aquarium. We were expecting a bit more but it turns out to be a fairly small aquarium. Also expected more animals. Finished the tour around the place pretty quick. Nice but not so great.
Don't Expect Seaworld and You'll Be Happy
Nice little aquarium. Not really that much in it but it's not too expensive. Definitely check out the jellyfish, they were the best part.

My wife was so cute enjoying looking at all the critters. We saw some scuba divers too and that was neat. The double door elevator confuses everyone, don't worry! We got to pet a ray, a shark, a cucumber and an anemone!

The Aquarium is nicely set out. It was ok, but honestly we were in and out in 30mins. Obviously, you can spent longer in there, as you can come and go all day, we didn't need to.
Younger kids would enjoy it more. Still a nice place to visit though.
Show less

My 11 y/o and I loved this aquarium. The underwater experience with sharks and other fish and the hands on pools to pet and feed sharks were our biggest highlights. Loved the jellyfish as well. Beware parents, there are fun things in the gift shop!
Go to Academy of Sciences instead!

Do not waste your money and time here. It is not a good aquarium. Decent jellyfish exhibit, but that's about it. Seems worn. Touch pool is only 2 rays, one who stayed where you couldn't touch him. Go instead to the California academy of science. Way way better aquarium with penguins, coral reef colorful fish, "twilight" dark dwelling fish, albino alligator, etc. Plus it also has an indoor rainforest, planetarium, and earthquake simulator. Much better experience and value for your money and time.
Show less
Enjoyed our visit to the aquarium today. Very busy and a bit crowded but staff Verbally educating was a joy. Several exhibits I've not seen before. Touch exhibits was a nice touch for the children.
Its a beaultiful place to spend some time with family and mostly with kids. There you can pet little sharks and see the amazing jellyfish show.

The river otters were so fun to watch. The entire aquarium is set up nicely. The "petting" area is fun with sting rays, a shark and some star fish. One of the nice attractions is that you can come and go all day. This was the only attraction like that. This activity was included with our Go Card (San Francisco). Highly recommend for families.
Show less

This little underwater aquarium is actually quite nice. It is situated at Pier 39 where all the touristy stuff takes place so I expected it time a bit cheesie. It turned out to be very informative, relaxing and like a mini Montary Bay Aquarium.
Small Aquarium located at Pier 39. Great for kids. Being at SFO Bay we kind of expected more after having been to the Long Bch & Monterey ones, but still a nice diversion from all the shops.

The positives about the visit to the aquarium are the tunnels that you walk through and you can see so many of the sea creatures there, up close and personal! And the touching ponds where you can use one finger to touch a starfish or skate. The less than positive are the confusing way to make your way around - you see one floor and then go on an elevator, etc. The first exhibits to the left when you come in could you better signage. (It's great that the signage is in English and Spanish and some Chinese.) The river otters have a very small location to swim around in. Overall, it is a small aquarium with a relatively high price.
Show less
Fine Thing To Do At Fisherman's Wharf

If you are tired of looking at the repetitive shops on Fisherman's Wharf, this is a fine enough alternative. Kind of expensive for what it is, but that's on par for a high tourist area. Small, but the underwater tunnels were definitely a highlight. Depending on how many people are in there, it takes 30-40 minutes to go through.
Show less
Enjoyed the visit to Aquarium of the bay. Watched the various species of fishes and other creatures of the sea at a single place. Enjoyed our visit
Small but fun with good info

This aquarium is small but has lots of info about the local area and marine life. There are shows throughout the day and they stamp your hand so you can return later if you would like. We were only there about 1 hour or so. Did this as part of our City Pass.
Show less

When my wife and I visited San Fran we went here and thoroughly enjoyed our visit. It was very interesting seeing all the creatures that live in the bay. I thought it was really well put together with really helpful staff. Ideal for visitors of all ages.
Show less

We visit every time we are in San Fran. It's small but very well done, with a new otter exhibit to entertain too.
I do think it's bordering on being too expensive - but I love it so much I'll keep paying - only two of us however, for a family it would really add up.
Fish, shark tunnel and otters - can't beat it for me
Show less

We were in San Fran and saw the aquarium. Our 10 yr old loves anything to do with fish so we had to go in. Not a massive place but what is there is good and well presented. There is a small rock pool area where you can touch star fish and sea urchins and also a small pool where you can touch baby sharks and Rays.
Show less

Worth the time spent there. I recommend any travellers with children as they will love it. My daughter along with 100 other kids did not leave the sight the fish tank which had Nemo and Dori. They screamed with excitement probably expecting these fishes to chat with them. These fishes are bigger than any celebrity. Children also get to touch some fishes including baby shark and also feed them, which is very exiting. The next wonderful attraction in this place are the Sharks of Alcatraz and as the aquarium is over head children love the fact that the Sharks are all around them.

This is not expensive at all and strongly recommend families with children to visit! The best part is that you can buy the ticket early in the morning and keep visiting any number of times whenever you want the whole day!
Show less

There are some great views to be had from the upper levels of the aquarium- both of the city and the bay. The aquarium hosted a "Fish Eye View" of Bay Area waters, including how the ocean dwellers have adapted to the litter left behind by those of us on land. The exhibits were well done and most were hands on interactive a for kids. More than a few tourists let their kids run wild, but it actually made it kind of fun- they were really excited to see sharks and an octopus and the jellies. If you're at the pier it's a great place to spend a little time and learn something besides shopping for knickknacks on the boardwalk!
Show less
It was nice, but small. A little pricey for what it is, espwcially for a family of 5, but the displays they do have were nice. Definitely a tourist trap, but was worth doing once.
Worth a visit without being totally awesome

We were in two minds as to whether to visit the Aquarium as some reviews had not been great but we were glad we went.

The staff were engaging throughout and in the aquarium itself, there were several staff explaining about the sealife and the Bay area, which we found to be quite helpful.

You can skip through the whole thing in about 30 minutes if you want to, or take a little longer to look at the various fish, listen to the guides and read the display texts - but you would be hard pressed to make your visit last more than an hour or so.

The real treat is the underwater walkway where you can see all the larger fish (and some small sharks) although a firm favourite of the family was the pool immediately after, where small rays were swimming around and bobbing out of the water as if to say hello to you.

There are other, more impressive aquarium, but the bias to the Bay makes this a worthwhile place to visit and we were glad not to be put off.
Show less
The Aquarium takes about an hour to go around. Very clean and well laid out. With time precious it is a good place to go you have limited time. Worth the visit
A Decent Replacement For Monterey Bay Aquarium

Though this place does not have the same grandeur ambiance of the Monterey Bay Aquarium 2 hours south of San Francisco, it is a decent substitution if you need to visit an aquarium. It has many of the same exhibits as Monterey Bay Aquarium except in a lot smaller scale. They have a decent jellyfish exhibit, a very small anchovy round-about swim tank, a hands-on touch tank and a very good glass observation tunnel. The first tunnel displays many of the local rock fish which is ok but nothing to rave about. However, the second tunnel includes large bat rays, sharks and bass fish, and it is a very strange feeling having a large bat ray swim directly at you as if it's going to ram you only to be stopped by the glass. If you cannot get to Monterey and need to go to an aquarium, this could be a good substitution, especially if you have young children...
Show less
OK if you have the right expectations

It took me about 30 min. to see everything. It's a nice and very small aquarium, so go in with this expectation. Look online for a discount coupon rather than paying full price. It's also kind of funny that all of the marketing materials talk about the 'Sharks of Alcatraz' showing a big set of jaws, and you learn that the most common shark in the bay is actually pretty small and not very ferocious. Kids will like the walk through tunnels.
Show less
Went to aquarium after Alcatraz. It was small and pretty average. It seemed expensive for the size of the aquarium ($25). Three small floors. A couple of long tunnels with sting rays and a shark.

We visited the aquarium one afternoon and it took a couple of hours to walk around. The observation tunnel is amazing, really long and lots of interesting sea life all from the local area. Staff seemed very knowledgeable and friendly too.

I've been to a few aquariums. This was ok but definitely not my favorite aquarium. It just seemed kind of boring. There were 2 long tunnels to walk through. There were a few interesting fish to see but it didn't seem like a lot of variety. Definitely did not see more than a couple of sharks and rays. It was crowded and just not really enjoyable for me.
Show less
Okay but expensive and too small

There are so many better aquariums in the world, it is hard to keep up with the others. I think the sting ray exhibit was good, and that was about it. They have one of those transparent walkways, which is good, but the type of fish is limited. Far too expensive however.
Show less

We love this place! Every time we go to San Francisco we visit. It is like having a peaceful moment in a very busy city. The jellyfish are my favorite as I can watch them fluff about for hours. It is clean and very family friendly! The tunnel of sea life is a treat not to be missed!
